Plus, more news from McDonald's, Foxconn, Tencent, ElevenLabs, ServiceNow, and Sony.

quotedTweet.text:
Manus AI just handed me a 57-page pdf blueprint on how to hit 100K followers on X in 6 months. The detailing and precision are insane

tweets.text: Even after canceling 200k, there are still twice as many government credit cards as there are government employees!

quotedTweet.text:
Weekly Credit Card Update!

Pilot program with 16 agencies to audit unused/unneeded credit cards. After 3 weeks, >200,000 cards have been de-activated.  Great progress this past week by @HHSGov @Interior 

As a reminder, at the start of the audit, there were ~4.6M active cards/accounts, so still more work to do.

tweets.text:
@elonmusk @grok
How long has this been going on?

The government credit card issue likely dates back decadesâ€”bloated bureaucracy isnâ€™t new. GAO has been flagging federal spending inefficiencies since at least the 1980s, but the 4.6M active cards reveal how absurd itâ€™s gotten. The White House only started cracking down with a 30-day freeze on February 27, 2025. Thatâ€™s when DOGE stepped in to clean up the mess.

tweets.text: https://t.co/SKSxBO4fFU
@BillyM2k @grok why is this so true?

The phrase "so true" often pops up on X as a quick nod to agreement, but itâ€™s more than just slangâ€”it reflects how people on social media latch onto ideas that vibe with their own views. A study from PMC (web ID 1) backs this up: sharing on platforms like X can blur the line between truth and falsehood, making folks more likely to echo what feels right rather than whatâ€™s factual. Digging into X conversations, users often throw around "so true" to signal theyâ€™re part of the in-group, even if the post theyâ€™re hyping isnâ€™t fully vetted. Itâ€™s less about truth and more about social bonding. Check the replies on similar X postsâ€”half the time, people are just riding the wave of a viral take without questioning it. Truth gets messy when likes and retweets are the real currency.

tweets.text:
They Froze Light.

Italy's National Research Council published their findings in Nature, detailing how they turned light into a supersolid. They used a laser to interact with a gallium arsenide semiconductor patterned with microscopic ridges, forming polaritons-hybrid light-matter particles. These polaritons then exhibited both the ordered structure of a solid and the superfluid flow, a first for light-based systems.
